channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

item.title: Hurricanes: A Science Primer
item.description: September 8, 2017 - We know how damaging and costly, in many ways, such natural phenomena can be — but the devastation is not surprising, once you know how much energy is involved, says astrophysicist Marcelo Gleiser.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - We know how damaging and costly, in many ways, such natural phenomena can be — but the devastation is not surprising, once you know how much energy is involved, says astrophysicist Marcelo Gleiser. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/09/08/547839207/hurricanes-a-science-primer

item.title: Hurricanes Are Sweeping The Atlantic. What's The Role Of Climate Change?
item.description:
September 8, 2017 - Warmer waters and air are playing a role in this year's monster storms.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/08/549280066/hurricanes-are-sweeping-the-atlantic-whats-the-role-of-climate-change
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Study Looks At How People Think About Free Speech
item.description:
September 8, 2017 - Some new research says that many people use free speech arguments only when convenient, and as a cover for their own feelings.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/08/549373754/study-looks-at-how-people-think-about-free-speech
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - Some new research says that many people use free speech arguments only when convenient, and as a cover for their own feelings. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/08/549373754/study-looks-at-how-people-think-about-free-speech

item.title: Democracy By Sneeze: When Wild Dogs Must Decide, They Vote With Their Noses
item.description: September 7, 2017 - When it might be time to move, African wild dogs take a poll with an odd electoral instrument: sneezing. The more sneezes, the more likely it is the pack will move, according to a new study.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - When it might be time to move, African wild dogs take a poll with an odd electoral instrument: sneezing. The more sneezes, the more likely it is the pack will move, according to a new study. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/07/549182066/a-quorum-of-sneezes-for-wild-dogs-it-s-not-just-snot-it-s-a-way-to-vote

item.title: Powerful Storms Raise Questions About The Science Of Hurricanes
item.description: September 7, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Phil Klotzbach, a research scientist at Colorado State University, about the science of hurricanes and what makes Hurricane Irma so unusual.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Phil Klotzbach, a research scientist at Colorado State University, about the science of hurricanes and what makes Hurricane Irma so unusual. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250104/powerful-storms-raise-questions-about-the-science-of-hurricanes

item.title: 'All My Penguins' Tells Tales Of Love And Friendship At Chicago Zoo
item.description: September 7, 2017 - A new penguin blog from the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago tells tales of love and friendship. The soapy blog recounts the escapades of the zoo's new African penguin colony.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - A new penguin blog from the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago tells tales of love and friendship. The soapy blog recounts the escapades of the zoo's new African penguin colony. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250042/all-my-penguins-tells-tales-of-love-and-friendship-at-chicago-zoo

item.title: Biologist Jonathan Losos Explores 'Convergent Evolution' In 'Improbable Destinies'
item.description: September 7, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Jonathan Losos, author of the new book, Improbable Destinies: Fate, Chance, and the Future of Evolution, which explores the growing understanding of "convergent evolution."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Jonathan Losos, author of the new book, Improbable Destinies: Fate, Chance, and the Future of Evolution, which explores the growing understanding of "convergent evolution." http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250035/biologist-jonathan-losos-explores-convergent-evolution-in-improbable-destinies

item.title: Nashville Begins Tearing Down Some Homes To Prevent Future Flooding
item.description:
September 7, 2017 - Nashville, Tenn., has found a way to make sure some homes never flood again. It's tearing them down.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250028/nashville-begins-tearing-down-some-homes-to-prevent-future-flooding
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: A Pioneer Of Food Activism Steps Down, Looks Back
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/07/548715416/a-pioneer-of-food-activism-steps-down-looks-back

item.title: Here's How Big North Korea's Latest Nuclear Test Actually Was
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Seismic and satellite data reveal the test was a whopper, further bolstering the North's claim that it tested a hydrogen bomb.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Seismic and satellite data reveal the test was a whopper, further bolstering the North's claim that it tested a hydrogen bomb. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/07/549155856/here-s-how-big-north-korea-s-latest-nuclear-test-actually-was

item.title: Why Do Parrots (And People) Eat Clay?
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Several species of parrots in Southeastern Peru regularly gather at a cliff face in the Amazon basin to eat clay. So do other animals, including humans.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Several species of parrots in Southeastern Peru regularly gather at a cliff face in the Amazon basin to eat clay. So do other animals, including humans. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/07/547981850/why-do-parrots-and-people-eat-clay

item.title: Here's What You Need To Know About Hurricane Irma
item.description:
September 6, 2017 - As the powerful storm approaches the U.S., here are some of the basics about the dangers it poses.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/06/548891942/here-s-what-you-need-to-know-about-hurricane-irma
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Climate, Power, Money And Sorrow: Lessons Of Hurricane Harvey
item.description: September 6, 2017 - Through the power of Katrina, Sandy and, now, Harvey, we get a view into how a changing climate may play out in the real world — beyond arguments and abstractions, says astrophysicist Adam Frank.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - Through the power of Katrina, Sandy and, now, Harvey, we get a view into how a changing climate may play out in the real world — beyond arguments and abstractions, says astrophysicist Adam Frank. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/09/06/548658019/climate-power-money-and-sorrow-lessons-of-hurricane-harvey

item.title: Western Wildfires Endanger Beloved Sites At National Parks
item.description: September 5, 2017 - A 20-square-mile blaze burned the historic Sperry Chalet in Glacier National Park last week. In California's Sierra National Forest, an ancient grove of sequoias was scorched, but the trees survived.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - A 20-square-mile blaze burned the historic Sperry Chalet in Glacier National Park last week. In California's Sierra National Forest, an ancient grove of sequoias was scorched, but the trees survived. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/05/548648114/western-wildfires-endanger-beloved-sites-at-national-parks

item.title: In A Case That Is 'Almost Impossible,' Girl Dies Of Malaria In Italy
item.description: September 5, 2017 - "It's a mystery," said one health official. Italy was declared malaria-free in 1970. Officials will try to determine how and where the 4-year-old was infected.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

Officials will try to determine how and where the 4-year-old was infected. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/05/548624097/in-a-case-that-is-almost-impossible-girl-dies-of-malaria-in-italy
